page.title: 01SOUTHERN FOREST OF DEAN
page.content: The 12 sq.km. grid lies to the south of the Forest of Dean. Most of this land, comprising hills and valleys, is covered by woodlands (coniferous and deciduous) and is worked by the Forestry Commission. To the east of the grid is mainly farmland together with an area used for growing fruit. To the south of the grid the land drops steeply to almost sea-level height towards the River Severn. Here are found the residential areas both on the hillsides and in the valleys. This area has little industry apart from forestry and only two of the roads are served by bus services. When walking along forest paths one can see many disused quarries and small drift mines which were worked earlier this century. The area's history dates from pre-Roman times and is renowned for its natural beauty.
